# Title

**Stats Project 1**

## Introduction

**The following statistical analysis concerns the flammability of childrenâ€™s sleepwear and the testing methods of five different laboratories. Five different laboratories received eleven samples each of the same fabric to test. Data was obtained by holding the fabric above a 1.5 inch flame for a predetermined period of time. The statistical analysis compares the mean ratings given by each laboratory in order to ensure that their methods are similar. We are interested in finding disparities between testing techniques from company to company and determine testing accuracy.**

```{r}
require(mosaic)
require(yarrr)
require(multcomp)
require(effects)
require(readr)

pj <-read_csv("pajamas.csv")
pj$Lab <-factor(pj$Lab)## sets the lab designations as a categorical variable

favstats(CharLength~Lab, data=pj)
pirateplot(CharLength~Lab, data=pj, inf.method = "ci", ylab = "Char Length (in)")

## Parametric approach
pj.lm <-lm(CharLength~Lab, data=pj)
summary(pj.lm)
anova(pj.lm)

plot(allEffects(pj.lm))## Effect plot of our one-way ANOVA1
par(mfrow =c(2, 2))## arranges the diagnostic plots in a 2x2 gridplot(pj.lm)
## Non-parametric approach

par(mfrow=c(1,2))
set.seed(1)
y1<-rf(100,5,10)
lm1<-lm(y1~1)
plot(lm1,which=2,pch=16)
plot(density(y1),main="Right Skew")

Tobs <-anova(lm(CharLength~Lab, data=pj))[1,4]
Tobs
par(mfrow=c(1,2))
B <- 1000
Tstar <-matrix(NA, nrow=B)
for(b in (1:B)){
  Tstar[b] <-anova(lm(CharLength~shuffle(Lab), data=pj))[1,4]
}
pdata(Tstar, Tobs, lower.tail=F)[[1]]

hist(Tstar, xlim =c(0, Tobs+3))
abline(v=Tobs, col="red", lwd=3)
plot(density(Tstar), xlim=c(0,Tobs+3), main = "Density Curve of Tstar")
abline(v=Tobs, col="red", lwd=3)
## Pairwise comparisons
pj.lm2 <-glht(pj.lm, linfct =mcp(Lab = "Tukey"))
confint(pj.lm2, level = 0.95)

par(mfrow =c(1, 1))## makes only one plot appear at a timeplot(pj.lm2)
cld(pj.lm2)

```
